                        IntroductionUnder climate change, destructive hurricanes and tropical storms are becoming increasingly likely to strike coastal areas in quick succession1. Sequential tropical cyclones (TCs) — defined here as two TCs making landfall in the same region within a short time period — can cause compounded damage to affected areas2. Unlike successive TCs occurring over several years, sequential TCs are marked by their temporally compressed impacts. When severe storms strike communities in rapid succession, the resulting loss and damage can be substantially amplified due to cascading effects and limited time for recovery between events1,2. For instance, a rapid sequences of three hurricanes (Dennis, Floyd, and Irene) that struck North Carolina between September and October 1999 triggered massive freshwater flushing and ecological disruption to Pamlico Sound, the lagoonal estuary in the United States3. A recent example is Hurricanes Helene (2024) and Milton (2024) which made landfall in Florida within two weeks. Hurricane Helene struck Florida on September 26 as a Category 4 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 140 mph, the strongest hurricane on record to impact the Big Bend region. It caused 225 fatalities, making it the deadliest Atlantic hurricane since Hurricane Maria in 20174. Less than two weeks later, on October 9, Hurricane Milton hit Florida as a Category 3 hurricane, inflicting repeated damage to homes, businesses, vehicles, and other infrastructure in coastal areas and claiming 24 lives4. The latest updated estimates indicate that the economic losses from this sequential TC event could reach up to $100 billion5,6.Preparedness for adverse events is critical for enhancing community resilience and enabling effective adaptation to emerging climate-related risks7,8. The National Academies define community resilience as the capacity of human and infrastructure systems to anticipate, absorb, recover from, or more successfully adapt to actual or potential adverse events, emphasizing the integral role of human systems in building resilience9. Communities act as the brain of the city, directing its activities, responding to its needs, and learning from its experience8, thereby highlighting their adaptive and transformative capabilities in promoting resilience to adverse events10,11. Unlike successive hurricanes that strike the same location over multiple years, sequential TC hazards impose a much shorter recovery interval between storms, presenting distinct and urgent challenges for community preparedness and resilience. When severe storms occur in quick succession, they can rapidly deplete resources, erode individuals’ mental well-being and complicate risk perception, ultimately diminishing their capacity and willingness to prepare for, respond to, and recover from consecutive hazards12,13,14. Worse still, the probability of sequential TC hazards occurring is projected to increase steadily1. Under a high-emissions scenario, the annual occurrence probability of two sequential category 4 or 5 hurricanes striking the same region could exceed 1% by the end of the century2. This emergence of sequential TC hazards highlights the importance of studying and investigating people’s situational preparedness dynamics for such hazards.At the individual or household level, TC preparedness includes short-term (e.g., evacuation, storing food and drinks, and reinforcing structural safety) and long-term measures (e.g., purchasing insurance, stockpiling essentials, and setting mitigation funds)15,16,17,18,19. A community’s preparedness for a TC event is not only driven by the meteorological hazards, but also by a range of intersecting factors, including its socioeconomic status, access and functional needs (AFNs), forecast weather information, prior experience with TC-induced meteorological impacts, infrastructure disruptions, and spillover effects. Existing research has widely identified the association between socioeconomic status and TC preparedness, findings consistently showing that those with lower income, minority racial or ethnic backgrounds, and lower educational attainment are often less likely to engage in proactive TC preparedness20,21. Particularly, individuals with AFNs, including but not limited to those with disabilities, limited language proficiency, restricted mobility, and economic disadvantages as well as children and seniors, face additional challenges in preparing for emergency events22,23. However, those individuals have received limited attention in research and practice24,25. Extant studies also recognize that risk perception of future TC hazards and prior TC experience would increase the likelihood of adopting preparedness measures26,27,28. Weather forecasts serve as the primary channel through which people access weather information, assess hazard risks, and take appropriate preparedness actions29. People take more active preparedness when they perceive higher upcoming risks (e.g., stronger forecast winds and heavier forecast rainfall). Prior TC experience also influences preparedness, as individuals who have previously faced such hazards may develop greater risk perception as well as confidence in their ability to respond effectively30,31. Particularly, severe TC experience (e.g., experienced strong winds and heavy rainfall) activates preparedness as people become more aware of the risks and the urgency for early actions. On the other hand, it is also possible that the affected community would develop complacency under repeated hurricane threats and fail to undertake preparedness measures13. A community’s preparedness is further influenced by spillover effects from its neighboring communities, driven by interdependent infrastructure systems, shared culture, and policy coordination32,33,34,35. Infrastructure disruptions in a region—such as power outages and road congestion—can induce broader impacts on neighboring areas by limiting access to essential services and evacuation routes36. Hence, even low-intensity TCs can cause substantial property damage and loss of life when preparedness is lacking (see Supplementary Note 1 for an example of Hurricane Ida (2021) casualties in different states). To summarize, community preparedness for storms is shaped by meteorological hazards and a range of demographic, socioeconomic, infrastructural, and informational factors, the dynamics of which are likely to become more complex during sequential TCs. Although previous studies have examined various drivers of community preparedness, none have investigated the mechanisms of preparedness during sequential TC events, a gap our study aims to fill.Regarding methodology, the existing literature has predominantly analyzed preparedness decisions using surveys either in the absence of disasters or long after disasters had occurred37. These surveys are typically cross-sectional and tend to focus on a specific region or a single event, thus failing to capture local adaptation strategies and policies over time or across different regions38. A complementary strand of research utilizes big mobility data to explore the dynamics of preparedness for individual hurricanes. Big mobility data are larger-scale, anonymized location data collected from mobile devices, which capture human movement patterns at high spatial and temporal resolutions39,40. For instance, Dargin et al. utilized GPS trajectory data to analyze preparedness behaviors for Hurricane Harvey, revealing a statistically significant increase in visits to specific points of interest (POIs) before Harvey, such as gasoline stations, grocery stores, and insurance carriers41. Deng et al. used high-resolution human mobility data to explore disparate evacuation patterns among social groups before, during, and after Hurricane Harvey15. Li et al. used mobile phone location data to examine income and racial disparities in preparedness for Hurricane Ida (2021) across multiple affected states16. Duan et al. leveraged smartphone data to uncover how the affected communities utilized cooling centers to adapt to extreme heat in the aftermath of hurricane-induced power outage42. Nevertheless, no existing studies have investigated preparedness dynamics in sequential TC scenarios. In the meantime, some prior research has provided initial evidence of temporal dependence in preparedness behaviors between sequential TCs, serving as a motivation for this study. For example, a study leveraging large-scale mobility data compared preparedness behaviors during Hurricane Ida (2021) in the affected states16. The findings revealed a lower preparedness level for Hurricane Ida in New York than in Louisiana; however, New York exhibited an earlier and stronger preparedness responses for Hurricane Henri (2021), which likely influenced subsequent preparedness for Hurricane Ida. To deepen our understanding of the temporal dependence of community disaster preparedness, we investigate individual- or household-level situational preparedness dynamics for sequential TC hazards using big mobility data.In this study, we focus on TCs that made landfall with at least tropical storm intensity (i.e., wind speed greater than 34 knots). We focus on cases where two TCs affected the same state within 21 days, the typical recovery period for a single TC event (See Supplementary Note 2 for the selection of a 21-day interval)43. We study the identified six pairs of sequential TCs that affected seven U.S. states (i.e., Louisiana, Texas, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Florida) between 2020 and 2024. Using big mobility data, we investigate three situational TC preparedness types (i.e., preparedness for mobility needs, daily supplies, and structural reinforcement) by identifying statistically significant increases in visits to POIs (e.g., gasoline stations, grocery stores, and building material dealers). We account for a comprehensive set of factors influencing preparedness behaviors, including forecast TC wind intensity, experienced TC wind intensity and infrastructure disruptions, access and functional needs, and socioeconomic variables. We designed a group of regression analyses to investigate (1) the combined effects of sequential TCs’ intensity and landfall sequence on people’s preparedness behaviors, (2) the role of communities’ AFNs in preparedness disparities, and (3) the impacts of first TCs on the preparedness for the second TCs. This study advances the understanding of the human dimensions of TC impacts, providing insights into disaster management policies for back-to-back natural hazards.ResultsSix pairs of sequential TCs landfalling in the US from 2020 to 2024We identified six pairs of sequential TC events between 2020 and 2024 in the United States, that affected seven states. Figure 1 illustrates the forecast track and the forecast uncertainty of the identified sequential TCs.Fig. 1: Six sequential tropical cyclone events in the Contiguous United States from 2020 to 2024.Red areas are cones of uncertainty and dashed lines are the forecast paths of tropical cyclones. Data source: National Hurricane Center operational forecast data archive74. Each cone of uncertainty is based on the forecast track issued 48 ± 6 h before its landfall in the state that experienced sequential tropical cyclone events (highlighted in gray in each subplot).Full size imageDisparate POI visit trends during sequential TC preparednessWe analyzed people’s visits to POIs during the six sequential TC events. We identified three situational preparedness types, characterized by statistically significant increases in POI visits before TC landfall: visiting gasoline stations to prepare for mobility needs, visiting grocery stores to stock up on daily supplies, and visiting building material and supplies dealers to reinforce structural safety, consistent with the findings of our previous works16,41 and existing literature44,45,46. Figure 2 illustrates the three types of POI visit trends during Helene and Milton and statistically significant preparedness pattern at the Brevard County, Florida.Fig. 2: Brevard County during Helene-Milton (2024) sequential tropical cyclone event.a Hurricane tracks and wind speeds in counties in Florida; b Visits to Points of Interest during Helene-Milton.Full size imagePreparedness for TCs can be driven by forecast weather information and the population’s concerns about potential extreme conditions. Also, counties within the same state may experience different intensities of TC due to variations in their distance from the TC path, providing a diverse set of observations. Figure 2a illustrates the hurricane paths of Hurricane Helene (2024) and Hurricane Milton (2024), which made sequential landfalls in Florida, affecting preparedness in Brevard County. As shown in Fig. 2, Brevard County experienced lower wind speed during Helene than Milton (13.8 ms–1 versus 35.4 ms−1) because it is far from Helene’s track. However, it showed higher preparedness levels for mobility needs and daily supplies observed for Helene than for Milton, while it showed a lower preparedness level for structural reinforcement for Helene. This finding implies combined effects of forecast intensity and landfall sequence on the preparedness for sequential TCs.We conducted analysis at the county level (i.e., all variables collected or mapped to a county-level resolution) to capture the aggregated individual- or household-level preparedness behaviors. We defined a county-level aggregated preparedness pattern as a statistically significant increase in POI visits before TCs, where visits exceeded two standard deviations above the baseline (see Methods for details). Analyzing the six sequential TCs listed above and the 680 affected county cases, we found disparate situational preparedness patterns across events and illustrated the patterns in Fig. 3. For mobility needs preparedness, 165 out of the 680 observations show county-level aggregated preparedness patterns for both TCs, 57 observations show patterns for the first TC only, 101 show patterns for the second TC only, and the remaining 357 show no statistically significant preparedness pattern. For daily supplies (structural reinforcement) preparedness, 163 (106) counties have situational preparedness patterns for both TCs, 44 (71) for the first TC only, 146 (92) for the second TC only, and 327 (441) have no preparedness patterns. The level of preparedness efforts, measured by the percentage of increase in POI visits compared to baseline (see Methods for details), also varies across preparedness types. For mobility needs preparedness, 241 of the 680 observations show higher preparedness levels for the first TC than for the second TC, and the other 439 observations show higher preparedness levels for the second TC. For daily supplies preparedness and structural reinforcement preparedness, the comparison is 272 versus 408, and 246 versus 434, respectively. The disparate patterns imply combined effects of TC intensity and landfall sequence (i.e., the first or second landfalling TC in a sequential TC event) on people’s situational preparedness, as investigated below.Fig. 3: Disparate preparedness patterns and preparedness levels for sequential tropical cyclones across counties.We define preparedness level as the percentage of increase in visits to Points of Interest compared with the baseline and preparedness pattern as the increase in visits exceeding two standard deviations above the baseline. Numbers and percentages of counties experience sequential tropical cyclone effects are shown in the figure.Full size imageCombined effects of forecast wind and landfall sequence on mobility needs preparednessWe performed spatial regression models (N = 1360) to investigate the disparities in the levels of preparedness for the first and second landfall TCs. Each data sample represents a county affected by an individual TC, distinguishing its landfall sequence with a dummy variable, where a subsequent TC is labeled as 1 and the first TC as 0. Linear models capture the continuous changes in the level of preparedness efforts and quantify the variances. We used the level of preparedness efforts, measured by the percentage of a county’s increase in POI visits compared to the baseline (see methods for details), as the dependent variable. Table 1 presents the regression results on mobility needs preparedness using Multiple Linear Regression (MLR, the baseline model) and Spatial Durbin Model (SDM). We presented the results of other supplementary models (Spatial Error Model and Spatial Lag Model) in Supplementary Table S1. SDM includes controls for the spatial lag of both the dependent and selected independent variables to return an unbiased estimate of the impact of the covariates of interest. Among the models we tested, SDM has the highest log-likelihood value (1342.42), justifying it as the most suitable model to explain the factors influencing preparedness for sequential TCs. In the following sections, we will mainly explain our findings based on SDM (i.e., Model 2).Table 1 Linear spatial regression models on mobility needs preparedness levelsFull size tableIn the SDM model, forecast wind speed, landfall sequence, and their interaction term are statistically significantly correlated with the mobility needs preparedness level. Specifically, every unit increase (i.e., 1 m s−1) in the forecasted wind speed corresponds to an average increase of 0.34% (95% Confidence Interval (CI): [0.16%, 0.52%]) in mobility needs preparedness. After controlling for other factors, second landfall TCs receive an average of 2.02% (95% CI: [0.45%, 3.59%]) more preparedness than the first landfall. However, the coefficient of the interaction term indicates that for each unit increase in forecast wind speed, the level of mobility needs preparedness for the first TC is 0.12% (95% CI: [0.01%, 0.23%]) higher than the preparedness for the second one. The marginal effect of forecast wind speed on preparedness level diminishes for the second hurricane relative to the first TC.The combined effects of landfall sequence and forecast wind speed reveal that populations are more alert to the second landfall TCs but appear less sensitive to forecast wind speed. From a psychological perspective, experiencing back-to-back hurricanes may lead to psychological fatigue, reducing responsiveness to risk signals such as forecast wind speed47,48,49,50. From a resource perspective, preparedness for the first TCs would consume essential but limited resources (e.g., money and supplies), leaving fewer means for subsequent preparedness for the second TCs18. These dynamics highlight that back-to-back hazards would result in compound risks for communities, and we will further elaborate on it in the Discussion section.Spatial dependence and state fixed effects in mobility needs preparednessThe spatial term in SDM (\(\rho =\) 0.4321, 95% CI: [0.3685, 0.4958]) indicates the presence of spatial dependence. The spatial terms in the spatial error model and spatial lag model consistently demonstrate the spatial dependence of preparedness between counties. Throughout the linear spatial regression models, we controlled for state-level fixed effects by including dummy variables for each state. We used Florida as the baseline category, so it does not appear as a variable in the SDM model. The statistically significant negative coefficients (see Supplementary Table S1) of Texas, New York, New Jersey, and North Carolina indicate that counties in these states have an average of lower preparedness efforts compared to Florida, holding other factors constant. Louisiana and South Carolina show no statistically significant difference in their preparedness efforts compared with Florida. This implies that Louisiana, Florida, and South Carolina share a comparable culture of preparedness among residents, likely due to their long history of frequent and severe hurricane exposure, along with policy initiatives and public awareness campaigns focused on hurricane preparedness.Access and functional needs potentially restrict mobility needs preparednessAFN factors in Model 2 exhibit statistically significant associations with the mobility needs preparedness level. The percentage of people under 5 (coefficient −0.0245, 95% CI: [−0.0287, −0.0203]), the percentage of people over 65 (coefficient −0.0040, 95% CI: [−0.0053, −0.0028]), limited language proficiency (coefficient −0.3465, 95% CI: [−0.5239, −0.1690]) are negatively correlated with preparedness level. It suggests that AFNs potentially constrain populations’ capability to visit gasoline stations for mobility needs. The proportion of people with disabilities and the lack of vehicle availability show no statistically significant evidence. We used POI density to estimate the resource availability for preparedness actions, which is also not statistically significant (coefficient-0.0017, 95% CI: [−0.0300, 0.0267]). This lack of significance may indicate that simply having a higher density of resources, such as stores and service centers, does not necessarily translate to increased preparedness51. Factors such as accessibility, physical mobility, transportation options, and public risk awareness play a more critical role in shaping preparedness behavior.Effects of forecast wind speed and landfall sequence on other preparedness typesThe statistical evidence of the combined effects of forecast wind speed and landfall sequence is weaker on preparedness for daily supplies and structural reinforcement. We illustrated the effects of forecast wind speed and landfall sequence in Fig. 4 and presented the full regression analysis in Supplementary Table S2. The combined effects are not statistically significant for these two preparedness types at the 95% confidence interval. One possible explanation is that the count of visits to grocery stores and building material dealers does not capture the extent of preparedness as effectively as visits to gasoline stations. Factors such as the average one-time payment amount, daily sales, and the types of goods purchased are also meaningful indicators of situational preparedness, but these aspects cannot be reflected solely by visit counts52,53.Fig. 4: Combined effects of forecast wind speed and landfall sequence on daily supplies and structural reinforcement preparedness.Numbers in the figure represent coefficients of variables, controlling for other variables. The 95% CI represents the confidence interval at a 95% confidence level.Full size imageFirst landfall TCs influence the preparedness for the subsequent TCsWe also developed SDMs (N = 613) to investigate the first TCs’ impacts on the preparedness for a subsequent TC, setting the preparedness level for the second TC as the dependent variable and the preparedness level for the first TC as one of the independent variables. Each data sample describes a county affected by two TCs sequentially. Table 2 presents the regression results for the three preparedness types (See Supplementary Table S3 for state dummy variables and spatial lag variables). Notably, the county-level preparedness levels for the two sequential TCs are positively and statistically significantly correlated across three preparedness types, mobility needs preparedness with a coefficient 0.8688 (95% CI: [0.7912, 0.9464], daily supplies preparedness with a coefficient 2.1030 (95% CI: [2.0019, 2.2041], and structural reinforcement preparedness with coefficient 0.9923 (95% CI: [0.9415, 1.0431]. This suggests that counties with high levels of preparedness for the first TCs also tend to have high levels of preparedness for the second TCs, potentially reflecting a learning or habitual effect developed after the first TC. This also reinforces our decision to account for county-level heterogeneity using spatial terms and fixed effects. Additionally, peak power outage from a previous TC potentially increases people’s preparedness for the subsequent TC. Every percent increase in previous peak power outage experience corresponds to an average increase of 0.12% (95% CI: [0.03%, 0.22%]) mobility needs preparedness and 0.25% (95% CI: [0.02%, 0.48%]) structural reinforcement preparedness. Maximum experienced wind from previous TC slightly decreases people’s mobility needs preparedness for the subsequent TC. Every unit increase in the first TC maximum experienced wind speed corresponds to an average decrease of 0.18% (95% CI: 0.06%,0.30%)). We did not find statistically significant associations between rainfall experience during the first TC and preparedness levels for the subsequent TC. This implies that rainfall experience has less immediate impacts compared to strong winds or power outages. One possible explanation is that rainfall-related impacts are not captured solely by rainfall intensity. For instance, flooding-related losses and damage depend on drainage systems, soil saturation, local topography, and other factors besides rainfall. We found statistically significant spillover effects of power outage experiences on the mobility needs preparedness (coefficient 0.2106, 95% CI: [0.0060%, 0.4152]) and daily supplies preparedness (coefficient 1.2568, 95% CI: [0.5610%, 1.9525%]) for the second TCs. The results indicate the spatial interdependency of infrastructure; power outages in neighboring counties will affect the preparedness of the focal county.Table 2 SDMs on the second TC preparedness levelsFull size tableThe county-level aggregated preparedness patternIn the aforementioned linear models, we measured the preparedness efforts by the increase in POI visits compared to a baseline. Considering that random fluctuations in POI visits could introduce bias into the assessment of POI visits, noise exists in linear models. To verify our findings, we used the occurrence of aggregated preparedness patterns as a complementary method to evaluate county-level preparedness efforts and demonstrate the robustness of the results. A statistically significant increase in POI visits indicates that the preparedness efforts are sufficiently high to manifest at the county level. These increases surpass normal fluctuations and exceed the baseline mean by more than two standard deviations, thereby highlighting a robust preparedness pattern.We performed logistic spatial models (N = 1360) with binary dependent variables (i.e., the presence or absence of county-level preparedness patterns) while keeping the same independent variables as linear SDM in Table 1. Figure 5 confirms the combined effects of TC forecast wind speed and landfall sequence. Consistent with the linear models in Table 1, higher forecast wind speeds are statistically significantly associated with greater mobility needs preparedness (coefficient 0.157, 95% CI: [0.084, 0.230]). Still, its effect diminishes for the second TC compared with the first TC (coefficient −0.068, 95% CI: [−0.110, −0.027]). We find the statistically significant combined effect for daily supplies preparedness, while the results of the linear SDM are insignificant. Given that the two models measure preparedness efforts in different ways, we consider this slight discrepancy acceptable, especially as daily supplies preparedness is close to significance at the 95% confidence level in the linear SDM. Structural reinforcement preparedness has no statistical significance in the combined effects. We consistently found spillover effects in preparedness efforts across counties. We presented the full regression results in Supplementary Table S4Fig. 5: Effects of forecast wind speed, landfall sequence, and spatial effects on the county-level aggregated preparedness pattern.Numbers in the figure represent coefficients of variables, controlling for other variables. The 95% CI represents the confidence interval at a 95% confidence level.Full size imageWe performed logistic spatial models (N = 613) on the second landfall TCs to further verify the first TC’s influence on the preparedness for the subsequent one. We used the presence (or absence) of the preparedness pattern as the dependent variable and kept the same independent variables in Table 2. The results show a statistically significant correlation between preparedness for the first TCs and preparedness for the subsequent ones (illustrated in Fig. 6), with a coefficient of 2.530 (95% CI:[1.964, 3.096]) for mobility needs preparedness, 2.084 (95% CI:[1.525, 2.643]) for daily supplies preparedness, and 1.418 (95% CI:[0.918, 1.918]) for mobility needs preparedness. The positive coefficients indicate that counties with higher preparedness levels for the first TC also have higher preparedness levels for the subsequent one. Also, we found statistically significant spatial lag in preparedness for the second TCs, with a coefficient of 1.162, 95% CI: [0.221, 2.103] for mobility needs preparedness and 1.091, 95% CI: [0.134, 2.048] for daily supplies preparedness. The results indicate spatial spillover effects in preparedness efforts across counties—a county tends to demonstrate high preparedness levels when its neighbors exhibit high preparedness levels. These results are consistent with our findings in Table 2. We presented the full regression results in Supplementary Table S5.Fig. 6: Effects of preparedness for the first tropical cyclone landfall and spatial effects on preparedness for the second tropical cyclone landfall.Numbers in the figure represent coefficients of variables, controlling for other variables. The 95% CI represents the confidence interval at a 95% confidence level.Full size imageDiscussionSequential TC hazards are becoming increasingly likely in the United States. The temporal compression of their impacts can strain community preparedness by quickly depleting resources, complicating risk perception, and limiting the time available to restock supplies, make repairs, and recover between events. To study situational preparedness dynamics during sequential TC hazards, we investigated three situational preparedness types, namely mobility needs preparedness, daily supplies preparedness, and structural reinforcement preparedness. We identified six sequential TC events from 2020 to 2024, which affected Louisiana, Texas, New Jersey, New York, North and South Carolina, and Florida, all landfalling with at least tropical storm intensity (i.e., wind speed greater than 34 knots). We found that forecast TC intensity and landfall sequence have combined effects on preparedness. Stronger forecast wind is statistically significantly associated with a higher level of preparedness, indicating people can perceive higher risks from the forecast intensity. Controlling for TC intensity, people tend to have higher levels of preparedness for the second landfalling TC in a sequential TC event. Meanwhile, people are more sensitive to the forecast wind speed for the first TC than to that for the subsequent one. Investigating the first TC’s impacts on preparedness for the second TCs, we found that experiencing a severe power outage from a previous TC would increase mobility needs preparedness and structural reinforcement preparedness for the subsequent TC. We did not see this pattern for daily supplies preparedness. We identified spatial dependency in mobility needs preparedness for TCs across counties. Power outage experiences in the first TC show spillover effects on mobility needs and daily supplies preparedness for the second TC.A higher level of preparedness for the second landfalling TC suggests that the first TC heightened people’s risk perception. Our findings support existing research showing that increasing risk perception can promote protective behavior in response to natural hazards, as reflected in a greater willingness to prepare and a stronger public response20,54,55,56. The consumption of household resources during the first TC may also drive higher preparedness levels for the second hurricane, as people need to replenish essential supplies. Another key finding is that the increasing forecast wind speed has a stronger effect on the increasing preparedness efforts for the first TC than for the second TC. It aligns with existing research on the anchoring effects that influence decision-making for future hazards, as people may rely on their experiences during the first TC to assess the risk of the upcoming TC57,58. Lower sensitivity to the second TC forecast wind speed can also be attributed to mental fatigue50, since natural hazards can induce psychological stress and mental health challenge47,48,49,59,60. People might also develop complacency or a false sense of security after surviving the first TC. Empirical evidence shows that the government plays a critical role in managing public complacency, especially as an information provider and preparation facilitator13. Therefore, it is crucial for local governments to communicate the ongoing risks of sequential storms and emphasize the importance of maintaining sustained preparedness and provide clear guidance on how to effectively prepare. Those efforts are particularly vital in coastal regions where the risk of sequential TCs is elevated. From another perspective, preparedness efforts for the first TC can deplete essential resources, leaving fewer means for subsequent preparedness. Hence, it is also crucial for the government to strengthen infrastructure and logistics systems to pre-position resources in advance or allocate them before and during sequential TC events. This approach ensures that communities are well-equipped to respond, thereby minimizing the compound impacts of back-to-back hazards.Our results suggest that power outage experiences in the first TCs would increase people’s preparedness for the subsequent TCs. It aligns with existing research findings that people worrying about power outages tend to have a higher preparedness for potential outages in the future61. Power outage risks are not solely driven by wind speed but are also closely linked to factors such as grid resilience, wind gusts, vegetation management, and land use62,63,64,65,66,67. We did not control for these factors influencing power outages as they fall outside the scope of this study’s focus on preparedness. Power outage experiences during the first TC exhibit spatial spillover effects on neighboring counties’ preparedness for the second event, indicating that prior disruptions influence regional responses beyond county boundaries. We also found statistically significant spatial lag in neighboring counties’ preparedness levels, suggesting interconnection across neighboring counties’ preparedness. These results suggest that county-level preparedness for an approaching TC interacts with neighboring counties due to interdependent infrastructure, sharing ideology, and policy coordination32,33,34. Additionally, state fixed effects reveal variation in preparedness efforts across states, suggesting that differing government ideologies on TC hazards may influence state level TC preparedness68.Our analysis reveals statistically significant disparities in preparedness patterns among individuals with Access and Functional Needs (AFNs). Notably, preparedness for mobility needs is most severely impacted when TC occurs, as communities with higher proportions of children under 5, elderly individuals over 65, people with disabilities, households with language barriers, and those without vehicles tend to demonstrate lower preparedness levels. These findings underscore the importance of designing targeted, inclusive preparedness strategies that address the specific challenges faced by these groups, particularly in relation to limited mobility during disaster events. It is essential to invest in emergency infrastructure that supports accessible transportation options, such as ramps, accessible vehicles, and safe evacuation routes. Additionally, inclusive transportation planning is critical, ensuring that public transit and emergency evacuation systems are designed to accommodate the diverse mobility needs of these populations.The increasing frequency of sequential TC events presents additional challenge to community resilience. Previous research on compound hazards mainly focused on simultaneous events, such as compound flooding, heatwaves, and storm-induced power outages69,70,71. Sequential TC hazards strike the same community in quick succession1,2. While a community could be resilient enough to absorb and recover from a single hurricane, the second hurricane might arrive during a vulnerable recovery period, overwhelming the community’s resilience capacity. Our study uncovered the disparities between preparedness efforts for the first and second TCs, the first TCs’ impacts on preparedness for the second TCs, spatial dependence in preparedness across counties, spillover effects of infrastructure disruptions (e.g., power outages), and the role of AFN factors in TC preparedness. Our findings advance the understanding of people’s preparedness for sequential TC hazards, while providing insights for improving risk reduction strategies to address the sequentially compound hazards and highlighting the need for targeted outreach and support to assist people with AFNs. Under the high emission scenario (i.e. SSP5–8.5), the likelihood of sequential tropical cyclone hazards impacting the same location within 21 days is projected to increase substantially by the end of the 21st century, with annual probabilities exceeding 50% across many locations along the US East and Gulf coasts1,2. By examining recent cases of sequential TCs, this study provides timely insights to inform community preparedness strategies and guide policymaking in the face of escalating future challenges.This study has limitations. According to the resilience lifecycle model, an extremely short interval implies that the second TC strikes while the community is still experiencing disruptions and has not yet begun the recovery process72. In such cases, situational preparedness may be low due to limited capacity instead of a lack of willingness. Conversely, a relatively longer interval facilitates preparedness efforts. We tried to incorporate the interval between each pair of sequential TCs in our analysis. Given the availability of mobility data and power outage data, the limited cases provided limited distinct values of intervals for observations, failing to facilitate a robust analysis. We did not find a statistically significant correlation between the interval between two sequential TCs and the level of situational preparedness. Moreover, due to limitations in data availability, we did not model flood severity. Although we included experienced rainfall as a proxy for flood potential, future work should explore additional datasets and develop more robust methods to control for the effects of flooding on preparedness dynamics. We did not model road network conditions or transportation disruptions due to data availability. Integrating road conditions and transportation disruptions in future research could help capture access constraints during extreme weather. In addition, our analysis does not differentiate between people’s willingness and capability to prepare. In high-intensity or prolonged TC events, people may be unable or feel unsafe leaving their homes to visit gasoline stations, grocery stores, or building supply shops. Future work can explore additional datasets and develop new methods to distinguish the impacts of capacity constraints from willingness on preparedness. Finally, future research could benefit from incorporating transaction-level data to differentiate between consumable and reusable preparedness resources, providing a more nuanced understanding of short- versus long-term risk mitigation strategies.MethodData pre-processingThe following sections introduce the data we used. We pre-processed all the data to county resolution according to the TCs’ affected regions and periods.Mobility dataWe used the mobility data provided by Dewey Inc. to assess situational preparedness during sequential TC hazards73. The mobility data reports daily visits to POIs and their geographic locations. To account for a consistent weekly pattern of POI visits (i.e., higher visits on weekends than weekdays), we calculated the 7-day rolling average of daily POI visits, representing the preparedness efforts in a continuous 7-day period. We defined the preparedness period for a TC as the 7-day period before its landfall. Setting a baseline for each county, we used the average of the 7-day rolling average from four weeks to one week before the sequential TC events (i.e., 21 days before the preparedness period). To estimate the preparedness efforts for each TC event, we calculated the ratio of the maximum 7-day rolling average during the preparedness period (representing peak visits to POIs in a continuous 7-day period) to the baseline value. A ratio value exceeding two standard deviations above the baseline represents a statistically significant increase in POI visits. We defined this threshold exceedance as the presence of a county-level preparedness pattern for the upcoming TC. We defined preparedness level as the percentage of increasing visits to POIs compared to the baseline, which is the ratio value minus 1. The presence (or absence) of a preparedness pattern is the dependent variable in logistic regression models. Preparedness level serves as the dependent variable in linear regression models.Using the POI locations provided by the mobility data, we calculated POI density for each county by dividing the total number of specific POIs (e.g., gasoline stations) in a county by the county’s land area.Historical windWe utilized the Best Track Data (HURDAT2) from the National Hurricane Center (NHC) to extract the paths and associated wind radii of TCs74. HURDAT2 provides data at a 6-h resolution, which we interpolated to a 1-h resolution. We used a TC wind field model to produce the TC radial profile of the near-surface rotating wind75,76,77. We recorded the estimated maximum sustained wind speed for each county as the wind impacts from the first TCs.Historical rainfallWe used the NCEP/EMC 4KM Gridded (GRIB) Stage IV Data to estimate historical rainfall during a TC event78. We averaged the values of gridded data points within a county’s boundary to estimate the rainfall of the county. To assess the rainfall impacts from the first TCs, we calculated the maximum rainfall volume over any continuous 24-h period79.Forecast windThe forecast information was sourced from the NHC Tropical Cyclone Archive, which contains all hurricane forecasts produced since the center’s establishment in 195474,80. These forecasts include track and intensity predictions generated every 6 h throughout the life cycle of a TC. We used the forecast maximum wind speed to estimate the forecast intensity of the TCs.Power outageThe Environment for Analysis of Geo-Located Energy Information (EAGLE-ITM) data, maintained by Oak Ridge National Laboratory, reports the number of customers experiencing electricity outages every 15 min at the county level81,82. To estimate the total number of customers in a county \({c}_{i}\), we used the following formula provided by the data publisher82:$${c}_{i}={p}_{i}* \frac{C}{P}$$
                    (1)
                where \(C\) is the total number of customers in the state, \(P\) is the population of the state, and \({p}_{i}\) is the population of county within the state. When \({c}_{i,{out}}\) represent the customers without power in county \(i\), the extent of power outages, estimated by the power outage rate in a county, follows.$${Power\; outage\; rate}=\frac{{c}_{i,{out}}}{{c}_{i}}$$
                    (2)
                Factors of sociodemographic and access and functional needsTo control for the effects of sociodemographic factors on TC preparedness and explore the effects of access and functional needs, we involved the county level household median income, percentage of white population, percentage of people under 5 years old, the percentage of people over 65 years old, the percentage of disabled people aged 5–65, the percentage of households with limited English proficiency, and the percentage of households without vehicles in our study. We collected the data mentioned above from US Census Bureau83.Statistical analysisWe performed spatial regression models to explore: (1) the disparities in preparedness between the first and second TCs; (2) the role of AFNs in preparedness for TCs; and (3) the first TCs’ influences on the preparedness for the subsequent TCs. The Spatial Durbin Model (SDM) assumes the spatial dependence exists in both the dependent variable and the independent variables, which follows the baseline specification:$${y}_{j}=\rho W{y}_{j}+{X}_{j}\beta +W{Z}_{j}\theta +{D\alpha }_{s}+{\varepsilon }_{j}$$
                    (3)
                where \({y}_{j}\) is the vector of county preparedness levels before TC \(j\). \(W\) is the spatial weight matrix defined using the Queen contiguity criterion. \(W{y}_{j}\) thus represent the spatially weighted average of preparedness among the neighboring counties of each county before TC \(j\). \({X}_{j}\) is the matrix of independent variables, including climatology, infrastructure, socioeconomic and AFN factors introduced above. \(\beta\) represents the coefficients associated with \({X}_{j}\). \({Z}_{j}\) is a subset of \({X}_{j}\), including factors affecting infrastructure connection between counties. \(\rho\) and \(\theta\) characterize the strength of the spatial dependence for the dependent and independent variables, respectively. \({D\alpha }_{s}\) represents state-level fixed effects. \({\varepsilon }_{j}\) is the residual error term. Alternative models include multiple linear regression (MLR), spatial error models (SEM), and spatial lag models (SLR). Each of these alternative approaches serves as a restricted version of the SDM, imposing certain parameter constraints.We employed spatial logistic models on the presence (or absence) of county-level aggregated preparedness patterns in sequential TC events to demonstrate the robustness of linear models. The spatial logistic model follows a specification:$${logit}\left(P\left({y}_{j}=1\right)\right)=\rho W{y}_{j}+{X}_{j}\beta +W{Z}_{j}\theta +{D\alpha }_{s}$$
                    (4)
                where \({y}_{j}\) is the vector of binary variables (\(y=1\) for the presence of a county-level preparedness pattern and \(y=0\) for its absence). Other terms remain the same with linear models.

Data availability
              
              The mobility data are available from the Dewey data platform (https://www.deweydata.io/), which were used under license for the current study. The access and functional needs data are available from the US Census Bureau (https://data.census.gov/). The hurricane Best Tract Data (HURDAT2) are available from the National Hurricane Center (NHC) Data Archive (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/data/). The 4KM gridded precipitation data are available from NSF NCAR Research Data Archive (https://rda.ucar.edu/datasets/d507005/). The EAGLE-I power outage data are available at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (https://smc-datachallenge.ornl.gov/eagle/). The post-processed data are available at the GitHub repository through: https://github.com/TLDuan-Purdue/Preparedness_for_STC.
            Code availability
              
              The code to generate figures and tables is available at the GitHub repository through: https://github.com/TLDuan-Purdue/Preparedness_for_STC.

items.title: Le prospettive di sviluppo del biometano dopo il 2026: l’Italia nello scenario europeo |​​​​​​​CIB OnAir Tech
items.description: Torna l’appuntamento con CIB OnAir Tech. Il CIB – Consorzio Italiano Biogas organizza un webinar per analizzare la situazione del biogas e
items.body:
Le prospettive di sviluppo del biometano dopo il 2026: l’Italia nello scenario europeo |​​​​​​​CIB OnAir Tech

26 Novembre 2025

Torna l’appuntamento con CIB OnAir Tech.Il CIB – Consorzio Italiano Biogas organizza un webinar per analizzare la situazione del biogas e biometano in Italia, alla luce del mutato scenario europeo. Sarà l’occasione per avere una panoramica di quel che accade in Europa, grazie a un intervento di EBA European Biogas Association, e per discutere delle prospettive del biometano post PNRR. Ad arricchire il dibattito, è prevista una una tavola rotonda con alcuni Soci industriali del CIB, che porteranno la loro esperienza nel mercato del biometano.Il webinar dal titolo “Le prospettive di sviluppo del biometano dopo il 2026: l’Italia nello scenario europeo” si terrà giovedì 11 dicembre alle ore 11:30 sulla piattaforma Zoom. È necessaria l’iscrizione.Programma Le prospettive di sviluppo del biometano dopo il 2026: l’Italia nello scenario europeoSaluti Piero Gattoni, Presidente CIBIntervento EBA Anna Venturini, EBA Policy DirectorIntervento CIB Marco Pezzaglia, Consulenza mercati energia CIBTavola rotonda:AB EnergyBioenerysPietro FiorentiniProdevalBright RenewablesWolf System
